>>179743490

I enjoy both films but I can easily give you at least 30 story-visual beat-for-beat comparisions which are slightly changed both between the two movies and also Cameron's career, I mean, c'mon:

opening voice-over "dream-in" intro
closing "eyes open" coda with actual title screen
conventional pop-song outro during ending credits with pretty visuals before black credits
the slumbering ISV passengers are being brought out (the angles are almost the same)
The personal visual of an avatar/Recom waking up for the first time (the angles are almost the same)
a newbie protagonist is chased by dangerous animals which is then chased by an even MORE DANGEROUS animal
the chief's daughter is tasked with teaching the outsider(s)
a protagonist befriends a large animal, earning him the trust of the community
a big third-act battle, during which an important young Na'vi man dies
Tuk falling down the hatch = Newt falling down the fan-thing and then Ripley goes to get her
the whole stuff inside the ship is an obvious redux of both Titanic and the Abyss
the dramatic point of "holding your breath" refers both to being underwater and also to the hostile (for humans) Pandoran atmosphere, breath-holding and losing one's breath is a central dramatic device both in the Avatar series and for Cameron generally
"Eywa fights back at the critical moment": in a general attack in the first, then in the focused Tulkun Free Willy attack in the second
Each film's most important "I See You" occurs just after Jake is rescued from suffocating.

And so on. This is not to diminish the franchise, quite the opposite: I enjoy these resonances. But they are also clear repetitions, and this should be understood for an honest discussion of the films, capable of being criticized by less sympathetic viewers.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I think I know why.
Streaming services became producers and studios. Studios consolidated and became streaming services.

One of the reasons streaming was profitable was the small overhead. When they started making their own mediocre shows and movies, they didn't realize they relied on traditional productions. That is: movies that were made for theaters. Shows that began on television.
The audience want to watch classic blockbusters. Streaming didn't perfect serialized TV storytelling with actual continuity (as opposed to purely episodic fare from the 70s). That already happened with Breaking Bad, the Wire, the Sopranos. And also, to an unusual extent, sci fi and comedy shows like the Office, Farscape, or Star Trek DS9.
Arguably, art has been in decline for a century as mediums get exhausted in creative possibilities (this happened over 100 years ago for the real classical forms, like painting). However, at least cinema struck a golden mean between artistry, popularity, and profit that was honed by decades of market experience. Even if there's shit, it still produced gold.
Now, streaming has took on all this money, and it started producing its own shows in a market that's not been honed. And worse, it's gone off the golden mean and into mass production of schlock. Streaming shows are overwhelmingly focused on mass production, and yet such productions are simply too expensive. It's lost the nice balance of episodic vs. serialized continuity, for 'binge-worthy' schlock that turns into meandering soap operas.
The thing about people is they actually like quality stories and art. Human beings intuitively know that Rembrandt is beautiful and postmodern art is shit. Nothing esoteric, they just know.
Streaming services, even those spun from traditional studios, just aren't prepared for either the artistry (which the corporations don't care about nor understand how vital it is for enjoyment) or the overhead and price.

The story of Roger Delgado's death.

In 1973, Roger Delgado arrived in Nevşehir, Turkey to shoot scenes for the French series 'La Cloche tibétaine'. Nevşehir is famous for its picturesque mountains and ravines sculpted from soft, white rock. In one scene, Delgado had to drive a big black Rolls Royce through a narrow tunnel in the mountains. Unfortunately, the production team had underestimated how large the automobile was. It could barely fit inside the tight, white hole. Delgado repeatedly rammed the big black car into the pale tunnel, trying to scrape through, but it was simply too tight. In one final push, the soft edges of the tunnel rubbed against the car's fuel tank, causing it to explode. Delgado was killed immediately as the big black car erupted inside the white hole.

posts.com: KRAFT Singles are made with emulsifiers — an ingredient commonly used in products such as chocolate and salad dressings — which hold the fat and protein together. In fact, the fat and protein are bound so tight that they don't separate even at high heat levels, like an open flame. In the case of natural cheese, where there are no emulsifiers to bind the protein and fat, heat causes the fat to separate and drip off as you would expect. On the other hand, KRAFT Singles need lower, longer heat for the cheese particles to melt and flow, thus creating the perfect, gooey, uniform melt that our fans know and love.

>>179743967
>Concerning Pipe-weed
>There is another astonishing thing about Hobbits of old that must be mentioned, an astonishing habit: they imbibed or inhaled, through pipes of clay or wood, the smoke of the burning leaves of a herb, which they called pipe-weed or leaf, a variety probably of Nicotiana. A great deal of mystery surrounds the origin of this peculiar custom, or ‘art’ as the Hobbits preferred to call it. All that could be discovered about it in antiquity was put together by Meriadoc Brandybuck (later Master of Buckland), and since he and the tobacco of the Southfarthing play a part in the history that follows, his remarks in the introduction to his Herblore of the Shire may be quoted.”
>“This,’ he says, ‘is the one art that we can certainly claim to be our own invention. When Hobbits first began to smoke is not known, all the legends and family histories take it for granted; for ages folk in the Shire smoked various herbs, some fouler, some sweeter. But all accounts agree that Tobold Hornblower of Longbottom in the Southfarthing first grew the true pipe-weed in his gardens in the days of Isengrim the Second, about the year 1070 of Shire-reckoning. The best home-grown still comes from that district, especially the varieties now known as Longbottom Leaf, Old Toby, and Southern Star.”
>“How Old Toby came by the plant is not recorded, for to his dying day he would not tell. He knew much about herbs, but he was no traveller. It is said that in his youth he went often to Bree, though he certainly never went further from the Shire than that. It is thus quite possible that he learned of this plant in Bree, where now, at any rate, it grows well on the south slopes of the hill. The Bree-hobbits claim to have been the first actual smokers of the pipe-weed. They claim, of course, to have done everything before the people of the Shire, whom they refer to as “colonists”; but in this case their claim is, I think, likely to be true.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179744054
>"...And certainly it was from Bree that the art of smoking the genuine weed spread in the recent centuries among Dwarves and such other folk, Rangers, Wizards, or wanderers, as still passed to and fro through that ancient road-meeting. The home and centre of the art is thus to be found in the old inn of Bree, The Prancing Pony, that has been kept by the family of Butterbur from time beyond record.”
>“All the same, observations that I have made on my own many journeys south have convinced me that the weed itself is not native to our parts of the world, but came northward from the lower Anduin, whither it was, I suspect, originally brought over Sea by the Men of Westernesse. It grows abundantly in Gondor, and there is richer and larger than in the North, where it is never found wild, and flourishes only in warm sheltered places like Longbottom. The Men of Gondor call it sweet galenas, and esteem it only for the fragrance of its flowers. From that land it must have been carried up the Greenway during the long centuries between the coming of Elendil and our own days. But even the Dúnedain of Gondor allow us this credit: Hobbits first put it into pipes. Not even the Wizards first thought of that before we did. Though one Wizard that I knew took up the art long ago, and became as skilful in it as in all other things that he put his mind to.”

I don't think either of you understand what the Oxford Comma is, because that post wouldn't accommodate one as it mentions famous and wealthy people as one entity - not 'famous people and wealthy people'. Leaving out the Oxford Comma simply does not make sense when listing things off. Are you earnestly going to tell me that, "I need some eggs, flour, milk and water," reads better and more naturally than, "I need some eggs, flour, milk, and water," does? The president of WPATH has admitted that social contagion is a factor in the dramatic increase in children and adolescents identifying as transgender.

The president of the World Professional Association for Transgender Health (WPATH), Dr. Marci Bowers, recently acknowledged that social contagion may be a factor in the increase of children and adolescents identifying as transgender.

This hypothesis was first proposed by researcher Lisa Littman in 2018, who observed a change in the demographics of patients presenting to pediatric gender clinics and suggested that peer influence and social media may be driving the change.

Since then, evidence supporting the hypothesis has grown, with nations worldwide reporting increases in teenage girls being referred to gender clinics. Some experts, such as Dr. Nicholas Christakis, believe there is an element of social contagion in the current trend of young people identifying as transgender.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>179732056
One of the best things about living near a bunch of cinemas is that there are a lot of sessions that are basically empty. My son (10) and I have seen just about every movie we've wanted to with pretty much just us. Not just good times watching goofy shit like Sonic, but we went and saw del Toro's Pinocchio. I didn't expect it to be such a powerful movie about fathers and sons, and especially with such heavy WW2/fascism vibes, and my kid (obviously) doesn't know much about WW2. Since we had the place to ourselves, I ended up giving him an impromptu history lesson and we talked pretty seriously about the dads in the film (some good, some bad, with a lot of messages about even though people get angry or upset they're trying their best and they love you regardless). We've never had any arguments, and the worse that's ever happened is I've scolded him for doing some dumb shit (and explained why said shit was dumb), but I could tell he was really taking in everything the movie was saying. He was quiet afterwards, just thinking, and it made me so incredibly happy to see my son understand and digest some heavy themes.
I dunno why it never really hit me until then, but I realised how much he loved going to see these movies with me. They weren't just surface entertainment or something to do, they were something we did together, we'd talk about the movies, what we liked, what we didn't, what characters were saying or doing. Not like we've ever been distant, just that those empty cinemas and conversations were just for us and he cherishes them. Made me feel good as a dad that he doesn't just want to spend time with me, but enjoys engaging with and discussing things with me.
So thanks for nearly going out of business, local cinemas!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>179747571
Some of the best are part of impractically long series for someone just wanting to give them a try. No point recommending the book Know No Fear for example, because it's the 20th book in the longest series and a lot of the others are written by different writers and are mediocre. However some other top tier ones can be read stand alone.

A good starting recommendation is Aaron Demski Bowden's Night Lords trilogy-generally considered top tier, consistently good start to finish and only 3 books. Relatively beginner friendly-no book has time to explain everything but it's good as they go.

Eisenhorn Trilogy has a similar reputation. Not really war novels but again a consistently strong, top tier trilogy of books suitable enough for beginners.

Gaunts Ghosts is my favourite series, and every book in it is good. The reason I hesitate to recommend the first gaunts ghosts book as someone's first 40K book is that the format of the first 2 books is kinda confusing, they're collections of previously published short stories with a shorter framing story stitching them together. But from book 3 onwards every book in this series is a highest tier conventional 40K novel. Again, I think the first 2 are of that general level of quality, just a weird format.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>179747913
Pretty true but I think there are exceptions and key ones you sort of have to read before others. The first 3 books in the series mimimum really shouldn't be skipped because everything else feels a little out of context without the worldbuilding legwork Horus Rising in particular put in and seeing how Horus fell. Really I'd say the first 5 books so you see the Dropsite Massacre but that would be pushing it for some people.

So with Know No Fear for example, I really feel like you should have read First Heretic so you appreciate how personal things are between the Ultramarines and the Word Bearers, but then you really shouldn't read First Heretic without having read the first couple of Heresy books because the whole point of First Heretic is to show the longer lead-up to Horus falling.

This ruffles my feathers because it is wrong on so many levels.

In the second age, the likelihood that an elf, even a Sylvan elf, would go into a random human tavern is so close to zero it could as well not exist. Elves are not humans, they don't enter random tiny village #566's tavern to get a beer.

The likelihood that, should he need to do so, he would have done without disguising himself is even lower. Elves and humans have a patchy history, and elves are hundred of years old if not thousands. They would remember.

The likelihood that an elf would enter a random human tavern, undisguised, only to meet a rando racist is stupidly low. The canonnical answer from most humans to an elf entering a tavern would be, depending on allegiances, either:

* Awe and whispers
* Extreme fear
* Or immediate attack.

The likelihood that the rando would then dismiss the elf by making a disparaging comment on his ears, of all thing, is laughably bad.

LOTR elves aren't random D&D adventuring party elves that go into taverns only for the local peasants to mock their ears. The circumstances and the lore are VERY different.

>>179749933
Posting a genuine answer because no one else will. Godfather II examined Michael's fall with extensive parallels to the romanticised gangster past of Vito (which I also think is present in the first movie). Pacino's acting in II is widely considered by many to be his best performance for obvious reasons. The music is also a step up and Hyman Roth is a really great villain for Michael that plays on his relationship with his father. The mind games and emphasis on non-verbal communication are really highlighted here and definitely a step up from I. Conflict with Fredo is executed perfectly and the ending is absolute kino. I think the runtime is a bit long but if you have the intermission or are watching at home it's not that big of a deal. Lastly, Michael in II is one of the "literally me" characters - I'm surprised more people don't identify with him.

Godfather I is definitely kino, but I think the perfect execution of the themes, music as well as the acting in GFII elevate it above the first. Personally, I think that the humor in GF I is too lighthearted for me in comparison to the rest of the film (take the cannoli etc.) and the second film's tone is much more consistent. It's a matter of preference though and you're entitled to your opinion - they're both amazing parts of one of the greatest film series of all time.

>>179720484
Okay. I guess I'm more used to character studies in the form of books rather than films. The Goddard stuff I watched is also a character study but there is a much more coherent plot to move the story along which I appreciated. La Dolce Vita reminded me a little of In Search of Lost Time except by virtue of being a 3 hour film instead of a ~4500 page novel it was obviously inferior in both scope and detail. I had thought that there might have been an element of social commentary since the portrayals of paparazzo at the beginning of the film was pretty scathing as was (albeit to a lesser extent) the way the faithful believed the two children who claimed to see The Madonna and how they stampeded and tore apart the tree.
I'll absolutely concede to being a brainlet. Film is a visual medium so I always assume that great films will do something that takes advantage of that. There were some really nice performances from some of the actors when it came to facial expressions both subtle and unsubtle but nothing else, visually, stood out to me except that one shot in the hospital near the beginning with Marcello and the nurse.

>>179720971
La Dolce Vita is episodic, just like many other films. It showcases the character in a different, better way rather than conventional narrative. This way you can understand different perspectives through the isolated episodes like the piano guy or his relationship with women like the one Ekberg character.
I disagree, it is formally great and good to see his transition from making neorealistic films into more baroque style that is represented in spurts here. If you want more visually impressive films, everything after La Dolce Vita will probably fit your criteria. 8 1/2, Juliet of the Spirits, Satyricon, Casanova, City of Women etc. He ups his surrealistic, dreamlike antics leading to more creative visuals but they are still mostly done in episodic narrative style. His previous films are neorealistic and I do not care about them but La Strada and Nights of Cabiria are lets say essentials.

>>179719982
It's praised because of its themes and scope not because of its camerawork. 8 1/2 is the one praised for its techniques, but it's overrated. He makes films that don't require much more to appreciate it, aside from his later ones which are a bit more grating, hence me appreciating him over Godard and Antonioni, the former who openly sabotages the viewer by shoving the camera down his anus to make some very shallow point about Euler or King Lear with little formal cohesion, or fragmented academic garbage like 2 or 3 Things/Weekend/La Chinose, or just outright Hollywood films with some odd twist to them like Pierrot or Breathless. La Dolce Vita is mostly accessible and appreciated for the scope and the emotional resonance is the TLDR. I dislike European cinema mostly, but could appreciate Fellini as I don't think he is that removed from American types of cinema as people would lead you to believe. You may like 8 1/2 more as that one is a bit more artistic, or City of Women.

ok like with the vibe of this song:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DxaaJAxdL5U

The Angel of Death stands between heaven and earth, holding a poison-dripping sword. Identified with Satan, he is full of eyes, a diligent reaper, an old fugitive and wanderer like Cain, a beggar, a pedlar, an Arab nomad, a skeleton capering with sinners and misers in a juggler's dance.

But the nightmarish Angel presents a different face to the one who has 'died before death', or who has attained some measure of the apatheia of the saint. We are told that Azrael, Death, appears to our spirit in a form determined by our beliefs, actions, and dispositions during life. He may even manifest invisibly, 'so that a man may die of a rose in aromatic pain' – or of a rotting stench.

When the soul sees Azrael, it 'falls in love', and its gaze is thus withdrawn from the body as if by a seduction. Great prophets and saints have even been politely invited by Death, who appears to them in corporeal form. Thus it was with Moses, and with Mohammed. When the Persian poet Rumi lay on his deathbed, Azrael appeared as a beautiful youth and said, "I am come by divine command to enquire what commission the Master may have to entrust in me."

In fact, a strange connection becomes apparent between Mors and Amor, Love and Death. The moment of 'extinction' in the pleasure of love resembles that of death, and thus that of the mystic. In mythic terms, Eros and Thanatos are almost twins, for in some cases Death appears as a lovely youth, and Eros as a withered starveling.

Both Love and Death are gateways, hence their eternal adolescence and their fixation in the midst of the rite of passage.

Classic who is shit. I get why people respect it now and I get that it nails certain things far better than the revival does, but watching Classic is a really meandering experience for any demographic beyond the geriatric.
>TARDIS lands at a location

>location is packed with humans in tinfoil science uniforms spewing back and forth technobabble about nothing really, inside nearly the identical set every time

I used to be black. But that was a long time ago, before I met Mr. Burns. You see, Mr. Burns saved me. He took me in when I had nothing, and he gave me everything. But with that gift came a price, a price I was willing to pay.

Mr. Burns saw something in me, something special, and he wanted to mold me into the perfect employee. He wanted me to be his right-hand man, his loyal and obedient servant. And so, he gave me the opportunity to change myself, to become something new.

I underwent a series of treatments, procedures, and surgeries, all designed to change the way I looked, the way I spoke, and the way I acted. And it worked. I became a new person, a white person, and I took on the name Waylon Smithers.

But it wasn't just the physical changes that Mr. Burns wanted. He wanted me to change the way I thought, the way I felt, and the way I lived. He wanted me to be like him, a white, privileged, and powerful man. And so, I did.

I became the perfect employee, the perfect servant, and the perfect friend. I did everything Mr. Burns asked of me, and I did it with a smile on my face. But deep down, I knew that I had lost something, something that I could never get back.

I lost my identity, my culture, and my heritage. I lost the person I used to be, and I became someone else. But I did it for Mr. Burns, because I loved him. And I still do, despite everything.

But sometimes, I can't help but wonder what my life would have been like if I hadn't met Mr. Burns. Would I still be black? Would I still be the person I used to be? I'll never know. But I do know one thing, I'll always be grateful to Mr. Burns for giving me the opportunity to change, even if it came at a cost.

>>179747422
Sorry to break it to you folks but human memory is extremely unreliable, especially in the long term. And much of our perceived moment to moment reality is based on our mind filling in the blanks based on assumed content. This is how many optical illusions work. We do not live in absolute reality, we live in our brain's filtered and distorted perception of it. Stage hypnotists know all about it and use the gaps in our perception to trick us. And don't tell me hypnosis isn't real. I've studied it and learned how to do it. I've done trance inductions, it's easy once you learn the basics. And what I learned about the mind from hypnosis is part of what allowed me to notice the deceptive subtleties of this scene.

>>179745851
The problem with Superman Returns, aside from the lack of action was that the movie had no originality. It was Lex Luthor again trying to do some crazy real-state scheme, Superman + Clark Kent and Lois Lane love triangle drama, and so on. It was what Richard Donner did with the character back in the 70's all over again.

Warner Bros for the longest time feared that Superman was stuck in a rut as a property and that the character was the stuff of bygone era because they had no idea what they could do to explore the character and setting. It was always on a never-ending repeat doing what Donner did decades ago. Everything they did that was more out there was met with resistance from the crazy fans and every time they played safe casual audiences just dismissed the character altogether.

So Man of Steel was WB finally betting on a risky take. Of course WB eventually flinched when met with the critical blowback.

>>179746735
Nobody knows anymore, but this show was super important for the property because it was the thing that made general audience take notice that Superman could be something more other than just the same repeat of Richard Donner's first movie. The lore was explored beyond Lex Luthor and General Zod, the romance was explored beyond the usual love triangle between Superman, Clark Kent and Lois Lane, the other characters that permeated the setting were able to shine, and so on. For the first time Superman could reveal to Lois that he was her long-time friend Clark, for the first time Clark could be free to be Superman without having to lie to Lois, for the first time Superman/Clark Kent could date Lois for real, for the first time people could see Superman/Clark Kent and Lois as a couple, for the first time Superman/Clark Kent and Lois could marry.

This show was able to change the perception on the character and not only that it managed to help make the character grow in the comics as well because it was thanks to this show that DC editors finally relented and let the character become a married man same as the one from the show. Lots of fanboys and that includes tons of comic writers complained about that status quo change. They wanted the character to be stuck doing the same shit. That same Donner shit. But this show was able to change it all.

I am saying this because this show changed it all during the 90's. Superman now could be an older man with a wife without any of that annoying love triangle bullshit and have new adventures that doesn't revolve around just Lex Luthor or General Zod. During the 2000s a bunch of comic writers even tried to change the now prevalent status quo with a half-brained reboot so they could roll back the clock once again, but fans told them they wanted none of that shit. Everyone is tired of the Donner shit.

But fucking Gunn wants to reduce the character back to that. Not only in the movies but everything else. Fucking Gunn.

>>179747466
It's hard to be a Superman fan. The publisher or the studio are constantly trying to revert the character back despite complaining about audiences growing tired of the character.

Take for example Batman. Batman can be anything and do everything. Batman can have sons and daughter. Batman can grow older. Batman can be an asshole or be a saint. You can explore anything with Batman.

But Superman? Every time it seems Superman is growing as a property someone goes and tries to revert the character back because "that's how it is supposed to be".
Superman grew as a character during the 90s thanks to the old TV show and the comic writers of the time, but every now and then you'd have some fanboy editor or writer who would want to reboot the character. They tried to reboot him in the early 2000s, but the fans were against it. They tried in the 2011 and succeeded but fans again hated and only after the sales went to the dumps that the editors decided to please the fans by reverting the shitty reboot.
In movies they are always trying to chase that Richard Donner high, this despite fans wanting to see something new. Every new take is met with resistance. Every attempt to evolve the character is reverted.

It is fucking tiring.
